metadata.case_name: Cooperative Housing Society (Appellant) v. Shivdasani (Respondent No. 4) & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant is a registered cooperative Housing Society under the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960, promoted by two individuals for construction of a block of flats in Bombay.
Shivdasani (respondent 4) claims to have paid entrance fee, share money and other demands; complains that his membership was wrongly rejected by the Society.
Society denies Shivdasani's statements and claim regarding payment and rejection of membership.
Shivdasani filed appeal under s.23(2) of the Act against rejection of membership, decided in his favour by District Deputy Registrar, Co-operative Societies, Bombay.
Society filed application before State Government for revision under s.154 of the Act.

State Government rejected Society's revision application on ground that orders under s.23(3) are final and Government has no revisional jurisdiction; intimated by Under Secretary via communication CAR/1064/426590/C-42 dated 17th May, 1965.
Society filed petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of Constitution in Bombay High Court (S.C.A. No. 1027/65), rejected by order dated 30 June, 1965.

High Court order: 'Government right in declaring no jurisdiction. It is wrong to say that respondent had withdrawn the application voluntarily. Attitude of the Society unjust. Admittedly the promoters were members of Everest Co. and they wanted Rs. 3,000 from each one for themselves. Societies are not meant for self aggrandizement. No ground to interfere. REJECTED.'

Hearing before Deputy Secretary, Agriculture and Cooperative Department on 10th March, 1965; letter from Shri M.G. Mani claiming Govt has inherent revisionary powers under s.154 despite finality under s.23(3).

legal_issues.text: Whether the Government is right in law in declining to interfere because it has no revisional jurisdiction in the matter, depending on construction of s.154 of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960.
Whether the finality under s.23(3) is subject to s.154.
Whether a party has a right to move the State Government under s.154.

petitioner_arguments.text: Government has jurisdiction under s.154 to examine legality or propriety of Registrar's order under s.23(3) despite finality clause.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 154 of Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960

petitioner_arguments.text: Party has right to apply to Government under s.154 for revision.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 154 of Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960

respondent_arguments.text: State Government has power under s.154 to call for records and examine legality or propriety, and finality under s.23(3) does not affect this power.
Power under s.154 is to be exercised on Government's own motion, not on application by a party; no duty to act even if applied to; no right to relief for applicant.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 154, Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960; Commissioner of Income Tax, West Punjab v. The Tribune Trust, Lahore; Julius v. Bishop of Oxford; Sheffield Corporation v. Luxford

respondent_arguments.text: Contrast with s.150 which expressly allows applications; s.154 uses 'may' as permissive, not compulsive.

court_reasoning.text: Finality under s.23(3) does not restrict Government's power under s.154, as s.154 applies generally to proceedings of subordinate officers except s.149(9); mentioning one exception implies inclusion of others like s.23(3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finality means not subject to ordinary appeal or revision, but does not touch special power conferred on Government by s.154.

court_reasoning.text: S.154 is potential but not compulsive; Government sole judge of occasion to exercise; can be moved by party but no right to relief or interference as in appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Party not prohibited from moving Government; applications welcome to draw attention, but Government may act or not.

court_reasoning.text: Tribune Trust distinguishable as Income-tax Act used 'suo motu'; here no such words, and practice allows applications without creating rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No right of relief as in judicial proceeding; mere application brings matter to notice.

court_reasoning.text: Government erred in holding no jurisdiction; High Court overlooked this and should have issued mandamus to Government to deal with application under s.154.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mandamus shall now issue to Government.

holdings.text: State Government has jurisdiction under s.154 to call for and examine proceedings despite finality under s.23(3).
Finality under s.23(3) subject to s.154 power.
Party may move Government under s.154 but has no right to relief; Government not compelled to act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, West Punjab v. The Tribune Trust, Lahore
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishable as Income-tax Act used 'suo motu'; does not prohibit parties from moving here.
Distinction between discretionary power ('may') and mandatory duty.
'May' is permissive or enabling; no duty to exercise.

statutes_cited.name: Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs membership refusal appeals (s.23 final but subject to s.154 revision); s.154 empowers Govt/Registrar to review subordinate proceedings except s.149(9); s.150 allows applications for review.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court petition seeking mandamus.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Government directed to exercise jurisdiction under s.154 and deal with Society's revision application; mandamus to issue against Government.
outcome.relief_granted: Mandamus to State Government to consider revision application under s.154.

key_quotes.text: "orders given under Section 23(3) are final and Government has no revisional jurisdiction in such a matter."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent

key_quotes.text: "The word final in this context means that the order is not subject to an ordinary appeal or revision but it does not touch the special power legislatively conferred on Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interplay of ss.23(3) and 154.

key_quotes.text: "Government may act or may not act the choice is of Government. There is no right of relief as in an appeal or revision... But to say that Government has no jurisdiction at all in the matter is to err."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies party's locus to apply without right to outcome.

key_quotes.text: "The High Court ought to have issued a mandamus to Government to deal with the application before it within its jurisdiction under s.154. That mandamus shall now issue to Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
